[Operator Instructions] Now I will turn the call over to Mr. Ankur Vyas, Director of Investor Relations. Thank you. You may begin.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to SunTrust's first quarter 2015 earnings conference call. Thank you for joining us.In addition to today's press release, we've also provided a presentation that covers the topics we plan to address during our call. The press r
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to SunTrust's first quarter 2015 earnings conference call. Thank you for joining us.
In addition to today's press release, we've also provided a presentation that covers the topics we plan to address during our call. The press release, presentation and detailed financial schedules can be accessed at investors.suntrust.com.
With me today, among other members of our executive management team, are Bill Rogers, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Aleem Gillani, our Chief Financial Officer.
Before get started, I need to remind you that our comments today may include forward-looking statements. These statements are subject to risks and safety and actual results could differ materially. We list the factors that might cause actual results to differ materially in our SEC filings, which are available on our website.
During the call, we will discuss non-GAAP financial measures when talking about the company's performance. You can find the reconciliation of these measures to GAAP financial measures in our press release and on our website, investors.suntrust.com. Finally, SunTrust is not responsible for and does not edit, nor guarantee the accuracy of our earnings teleconference transcripts provided by third parties. The only authorized live and archived webcast are located on our website.
With that, I'll now turn the call over to Bill.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ankur, and good morning, everyone.I'll begin with a brief overview of the quarter and then turn it over to Aleem for some additional details. Following Aleem'a comments, I'll wrap up our prepared remarks by reviewing our performance at the busin
componenttext:
Thanks, Ankur, and good morning, everyone.
I'll begin with a brief overview of the quarter and then turn it over to Aleem for some additional details. Following Aleem'a comments, I'll wrap up our prepared remarks by reviewing our performance at the business segment level and then of course, we will take some Q&A.
Earnings per share for the quarter was $0.78 on net income to common of $411 million, that was up 7% per share relative to a year ago. Overall, this quarter results were solid, with good performance in certain areas, including continued expense discipline, higher mortgage and capital markets-related income, strong credit quality and further deposit growth momentum.  These favorable chance helped us to counteract the decline and net interest margin over the past year. 
Total revenue declined compared to both prior quarter and prior year, entirely due to the lower net interest income, much of which was anticipated as the prolonged low-interest rate environment continues to pressure asset yields.  Partially offsetting this was an improvement in noninterest income, driven by an increase in mortgage and capital markets related revenue. 
Current quarter expenses were relatively stable to the adjusted level in the fourth quarter, as seasonally higher personnel costs were offset by reductions in most other operating expense categories, though portion of these declines were seasonal or nonrecurring in nature. More importantly, expenses were down to 3% from the prior year adjusted level as a result of continued expense management efforts, lower operating costs, a lower operating losses and the sale of RidgeWorth.  The combination of these revenue and expense trends resulted in an adjustable tangible efficiency ratio of 64.4% for the current quarter, slightly below the first quarter of last year. 
As we noted in January, year-over-year improvements in 2015 will be less than last year as we continue to work towards our goal of being sub-63 for the full year.
Average performing loans were stable sequentially, due in part to low sale activity quarter and elevated paydown activity in the current quarter, but also due to our strategic focus on overall returns. While we remain confident in our loan production capacity and the improvement economic conditions in our markets and businesses, our focus on returns will remain high and may impact ultimate on balance sheet loan growth.
Average client deposits were up 3% compared to the prior quarter, with broad-based growth across consumer, private wealth and wholesale businesses. Our core growth initiatives are gaining momentum, driven by improved focus, better execution and enhanced capabilities.
Asset quality continues to be an area of strength. Nonperforming loans were down 3% from prior quarter and 34% from prior year. The net charge-off ratio was 30 basis points relatively stable to the prior quarter and year. 
Our capital position improved with the our Common Equity Tier 1 ratio estimated to be 9.8% on the Basel III fully phased-in basis. Also, tangible book value per share continues to steadily increase, up 2% sequentially and 10% compared to the prior year.
Lastly, our capital, the capital plan that we submitted as part of this year's CCAR process received no objection by the Federal Reserve. Our common stock dividend will increase 20% subject to board approval, and we will repurchase $875 million worth of common stock over the coming 5 quarters, which is 55% higher than our previous share buyback authorization.
We're pleased that our strong capital position improved earnings power and reduced risk profile enabled this positive outcome for our shareholders.
So to recap the year-over-year trends. Net interest income declined, most of which was related to the anticipated step down in the commercial loans swap income. Noninterest income trends were solid and they more than offset the loss of RidgeWorth revenues. And lastly, expenses continue to be well-managed and asset quality is strong, both of which played an important role in mitigating the pressure on the margin and thus keeping us on an overall positive trajectory.
So with that as an overview, let me turn it over to Aleem for a for some more details.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bill. Good morning, everybody, thank you for joining us this morning. I'll begin my comments on Slide 4. Earnings per share in the first quarter were $0.78, which was $0.10 lower than the fourth quarter on an adjusted basis, and $0.05 or 7% hig
componenttext:
Thank you, Bill. Good morning, everybody, thank you for joining us this morning. I'll begin my comments on Slide 4. Earnings per share in the first quarter were $0.78, which was $0.10 lower than the fourth quarter on an adjusted basis, and $0.05 or 7% higher than the first quarter of last year.
The sequential decline was driven by a lower net interest income and seasonally higher compensation expenses and was partially offset by higher mortgage-related income and lower provision expense.
Compared to the first quarter of last year, EPS growth was driven by the continued expense discipline, a lower provision expense and higher mortgage and capital markets related revenue, which together, more than offset the decline in interest income and the return to a more normal tax rate. In addition, certain discrete recoveries, which I will discuss later, also contributed to the solid year-over-year EPS growth.
We'll now review the underlying trends in more detail, starting on Slide 5. Net interest income declined $73 million relative to the prior quarter, primarily driven by the anticipated decline in commercial loan swap income and 2 fewer days, but also impacted by higher premium amortization expense and the securities portfolio. 
Net interest margin declined 13 basis points, primarily due to lower swap income and the higher premium amortization expense, but also due to continued core margin pressure as a result of the low interest rate and competitive environment.
Relative to the guidance we provided in January, the higher premium amortization expense negatively impacted NIM more than we had anticipated as 10-year rates declined another 30 basis points sequentially. Conversely, mortgage-related revenues benefited from the decline in rates, which I will discuss later.
Core C&I loan yields, excluding swap income, declined 7 basis points, as new production yields continued to be lower than portfolio yields. We remain focused on ensuring that we both meet the full suite of our wholesale clients' needs and also, our own return requirements. When we cannot achieve this, we will look to either exit the lending relationship via targeted loan sales as we have done in the past couple of quarters, or simply not participate during future renewal opportunities.
On a year-over-year basis, net interest income declined $64 million, primarily driven by the same factors as the sequential drivers, but partially mitigated by 7% average earning asset growth. 
Looking forward, and all else equal, we expect second quarter net interest margin to decline approximately 2 [ph] to 4 [ph] basis points from the first quarter level, driven primarily by lower C&I loan yields.
We have been and we'll continue to carefully manage the usage and duration of our overall balance sheet in light of the continued low-interest rate environment while also being cognizant of controlling interest rate risks in advance of what we expect will eventually be higher interest rates.
Moving on to Slide 6. Adjusted noninterest income increased to $9 million from the prior quarter, primarily driven by higher mortgage production and trading income, which offset seasonal declines in other noninterest income categories. 
Mortgage production income increased $22 million due to higher production volume as a result of elevated refinance activity and improved gain-on-sale margins. On the other hand, mortgage servicing income declined $10 million as in the K expense increased given the first quarter decline in market rates.
Investment banking income declined $12 million sequentially, largely due to typical patterns of client activity between the fourth and first quarter. However, the $97 million of investment banking income this quarter is a record for a first quarter, with particular strength in investment-grade debt and equity capital markets businesses.
Trading income increased $15 million as the result of both higher client activity levels and the negative valuation adjustments in the prior quarter.
Service charges for deposits and card fees were collectively down $13 million due both to fewer days in the quarter and reduced incidence rates. Other noninterest income was higher, almost entirely due to an $18 million pretax gain recognized upon the sale of legacy Affordable Housing properties. As you'll recall, we recognized an impairment last year when we made the decision to exit these properties. Market values are now higher, and those sales are now largely complete.
Compared to the first quarter of last year, adjusted noninterest income increased to $12 million, as higher production income and capital markets related revenue more than offset the loss of RidgeWorth income.
Moving on to expenses. Adjusted noninterest expense increased $16 million relative to the prior quarter. Personnel expense increased $100 million sequentially as a result of typical first quarter FICA and 401(k) costs, as well as the return to more normal levels of incentives and benefit accruals. 
Outside processing and software costs declined $17 million, as the fourth quarter had elevated expenses, mostly due to normal timing patterns of rendering service and costs associated with replacing specific software.
Marketing and customer development expense also declined $16 million due to typical seasonality. Other noninterest expense declined $35 million due to higher legal and consulting costs in the fourth quarter, alongside $17 million of discrete recoveries realized in the first quarter. Operating losses declined $15 million on an adjusted basis, in part due to the recoveries of previously recorded mortgage-related losses.
Compared to the first quarter of last year, adjusted noninterest expense was down 3%, driven by a combination of the sale of RidgeWorth, discrete recoveries in the current quarter and our continued overall discipline around expense management.
As you can see on Slide 8, our adjusted tangible efficiency ratio was 64.4% in the first quarter, 50 basis points better than last year. We delivered this improvement despite the expected $50 million step-down in commercial loan swap income, as adjusted expenses were lower by 3%. 
As we have noted before, improvement in 2015 will be more challenging given our significant progress last year in addition to lower commercial loan swap income this year.  However, our performance this quarter demonstrates solid progress towards our goal. 
We continue to remain focused on the efficiency ratio and our goal of being below 63% for the full year. And as such, we will continue to exhibit strong expense discipline in light of the current revenue environment.
Turning to Slide 9. Our asset quality performance continues to be strong. Nonperforming loans declined 3% sequentially and are down 34% compared to the prior year. The net charge-off ratio was 30 basis points in the first quarter, stable with previous quarterly levels, as charge-offs continue to stay low. However, recoveries were lower than the run rate experienced in 2014.
With respect to our energy portfolio, we have not seen any meaningful delinquencies or defaults. During the quarter, we updated credit ratings, resulting in some migration and we expect that to be ongoing, which is why we have proactively built reserves for this portfolio. 
Our allowance for loan and lease losses and provision expense declined $44 million and $19 million, respectively, compared to the previous quarter. These reductions were driven by the continued improvement in asset quality, combined with the lower loan growth during the quarter.
Over the near-term, we expect further, though moderating declines in nonperforming loans, primarily driven by the residential portfolio. Net charge-off ratios are likely to remain within the 30 to 40 basis points range in the near term, though any given quarter, may be impacted by discrete items, particularly given today's low overall net charge-off rates.
We now expect full year 2015 provision expense to be below full year 2014 expense, as asset quality continues to improve, which is modestly better than our previous guidance. As you know, the ultimate level of reserves and provision expense will be determined by our rigorous quarterly review process, which is informed by trends in our loan portfolio, combined with a view on future economic conditions.
Let's turn to the balance sheet. Average performing loans were stable relative to last quarter as a result of loan sale activity in the prior quarter and elevated pay-downs in the first quarter, in addition to lower production as a result of our continued focus on returns. 
C&I loan growth, while somewhat slower, was positive and broad-based, driven by our corporate, commercial and small business clients. Consumer Direct loans were also nicely higher, given continued growth in our LightStream business and GreenSky partnership.
As you'll recall, we sold $2 billion of loans in the prior quarter which impacted sequential average loan growth -- sequential average growth rates. In addition, we moved approximately $400 million of loans to held-for-sale in the current quarter, which modestly impacted end of period growth.
On a year-over-year basis, average performing loans increased $5.1 billion or 4%, driven by broad-based growth across most portfolios outside of the residential, guaranteed student and indirect auto portfolios where the declines are consistent with our balance sheet optimization goals of better diversification and higher returns.
Going forward, we continue to seek opportunities to help finance our clients growth plans, particularly given the solid economic conditions in our markets. We will also continue to keep the high focus on improving returns and ensuring new business exceeds our cost of capital.
Turning to deposit performance. Average client deposits were up $3.6 billion or 3% compared to the prior quarter and 9% compared to the prior year, driven by broad-based growth across all of our lines of business. We're pleased with the momentum on the deposit front. Our success here effects our overall focus on meeting our clients deposit and payment needs, supplemented by investments in client-facing platforms and people across both our consumer and private wealth and wholesale segment.  Rates paid on deposits were stable sequentially and declined by 3 basis points compared to the prior year.
Slide 12 provides an update on our capital position. Common Equity Tier 1 expanded by approximately $200 million during the quarter as a result of growth in retained earnings, while the Basel III Common Equity Tier 1 ratio estimated on now fully phased-in basis increased to 9.8%. Tangible book value per share increased 2% from the prior quarter and a full 10% compared to the prior year, due primarily to growth in retained earnings.
As Bill noted, the Federal Reserve did not object to the capital plan we submitted in conjunction with the 2015 CCAR process. The capital plan includes a share buyback program of up to $875 million over the coming 5 quarters, which will be conducted relatively evenly on a quarterly basis, in addition to a 20% increase in our quarterly common stock dividend from $0.20 to $0.24, subject to board approval.
Lastly, our liquidity coverage ratio continued to exceed the January 1, 2016 requirement of 90%. 
With that, I'll now turn things back over to Bill to cover our business segment performance.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Aleem, and I'll start on Slide 13. In our consumer and Private Wealth Management, segment revenues were up 2% compared to the prior year due predominantly to higher net interest income, average loans have been relatively flat. However, we've
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, Aleem, and I'll start on Slide 13. In our consumer and Private Wealth Management, segment revenues were up 2% compared to the prior year due predominantly to higher net interest income, average loans have been relatively flat. However, we've had solid growth in our higher return portfolios such as Consumer Direct and credit card, which is offset the intentional reductions we've made in the indirect auto and guaranteed student portfolios.
This shifted portfolio mix is consistent with our overall strategy to improve returns across the company.  Also contributing to the increase in net interest income was 7% year-over-year deposit growth. Our improvements in deposit growth can be attributed to a more relentless focus supplemented by additional teammate investment, particularly in our mass to fluent high net worth segment and better technology, with our SummitView platform being one of the notable examples.
Noninterest income declined 6% compared to the prior quarter, largely due to seasonal declines in service charges and card fees. Compared to the prior year, noninterest income was essentially flat. While retail investment income growth diminished a bit, the quality of this income line is improving as the higher percentage is related to client assets under management versus more transaction-based revenue.
Growing Wealth Management-related income overall continues to be our strategic priority. Expenses were up 2% compared to the prior year, largely due to increased outside processing costs and certain discrete nonrecurring charges. Staff expenses remained relatively flat as ongoing efficiency savings offset continued investments associated with the revenue growth initiatives.
Lastly, despite solid 4% year-over-year growth in pre-provision net revenue, net income was down 3% as provision expense increased due to moderating asset quality improvements. However, overall asset quality continues to be very strong in this segment. 
So to recap, this is a difficult operating environment for this business as you know, but we are generating good core momentum for the long term. In the near-term, continued expense discipline will be important to help combat the revenue pressures that are associated with low interest rates and consumer service charges.
Turning to wholesale. Wholesale Banking continues to be a key growth engine for the company. Looking at the numbers on an adjusted basis, net income was up 18% year-over-year driven by solid revenue growth and further asset quality improvement. Adjusted revenue grew 8% relative to the prior year. Net interest income was up 9%, driven by broad-based loan and deposit growth, though this was partially offset by a decline in loan spreads.  Loan growth was 2% sequentially and 15% year-over-year, driven by growth across most of our client segments.  
However, given the competitive environment sent continued low-rate environment, C&A production yields continue to be pressured and as such, we reduced growth or sold loans in areas that are not meeting our long-term return hurdles. 
Deposits were up 4% sequentially and 12% year-over-year, and the success here can be attributed to enhancements in our Treasury and payment product offerings, along with the success of our liquidity specialist hires, both allowing us to uncover and meet more of our wholesale clients deposit needs.
Adjusted noninterest income was up 6% over the prior year driven by higher investment banking and trading revenue, reflecting the investments we've made in talent and capabilities to increase our market share. While syndications and leveraged finance volumes were down year-over-year, investment-grade debt and equity capital markets at record quarters and overall, as of Aleem mentioned, this was our best first quarter for investment banking income.
This overall performance is a testament to the enhanced diversity of our platform, both our product and industry, and as a result of the continuous investments we've made hin the business. Going forward, wer focused on leveraging the investments for the central swap to better meet the capital markets and advisory needs of our commercial banking, CRE and private wealth clients.
Adjusted noninterest expense was higher year-over-year, largely due to the investments in CIB. However, this business continues to have an efficiency ratio which is very accretive to the overall company. 
Overall, we continue to believe that our Wholesale Banking business is highly differentiated and our value proposition continues to be very well received by clients.
Lower loan yields will continue to be a challenge, and we're working hard to mitigate that impact by being more selective by utilization of the balance sheet in addition to continue to expand our fee income and deposit opportunities.
Looking forward, our clients remain confident, our investment banking backlog and loan and deposit pipelines are healthy and we remain bullish on the overall growth and profitability outlook for this segment.
Now moving to the mortgage segment where we had another good quarter. Adjusted net income was stable to the prior quarter, but up $42 million over the prior year. Our expense base continues to decline, while our risk profile was improving, both of which are key components of our strategy in this business. In addition, a strong refinance environment boosted production income in the first quarter.
Getting into the details, revenues were up 8% year-over-year driven primarily by higher mortgage production income as a result of a 64% increase in production volume and a higher gain-on-sale margins. Compared to the prior quarter, revenues were basically flat as higher production income was offset by higher decay in the servicing portfolio and lower spreads on the loan portfolio, a reflection of the natural hedge within the business.
While mortgage production volume was up 8% sequentially, application volume was up 48%, which should support elevated levels of production income into the near-term. 
The current refinance environment will abate when rates begin to rise, however, we expect purchase volume and our operating markets will continue to strengthen given overall economic conditions. Our expectation is supported by a purchase volume and applications being up 16% and 30%, respectively, year-over-year.
Adjusted expenses were down 5% sequentially and year-over-year despite higher revenue, primarily due to declines in operating losses and other cyclical costs. Additionally, asset quality continues to improve with delinquencies nonperformers, net charge-offs continuing on a declining trend.
So to summarize the quarter for the overall company, we had a solid momentum across each of our businesses which help mitigate the impact of the persistently low-interest rate environment on our net interest margin. Our focus on returns will remain a priority and the capacity we've built throughout the company should help us to continue and deliver a profitable growth.
In addition, we're mindful of the intense expense discipline required to operate in this environment and improve our efficiency ratio. This expense discipline will also be important to help fund continued growth investments, many of which are already yielding positive results so that we can continue to deliver long-term value for our clients and our shareholders.
Now with that, let me turn it back over to you, Ankur.

I was wondering as you look out now, have you gotten us down to a sub-$1.3 billion x [ph] -- quarterly expense run rate and if not the motor the upward pressures that we would see from here?

componenttext: Yes, can, this is Bill. The -- as you pointed out, we've been operating clearly, at the low end of the range we established which was sort of $1.3 billion to $1.5 billion. And I think we'll sort of continue in that lower end of the range. I think $1.3 billion, subject to some variation, is honing in on more of the right number given where we are in this environment.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ken, you know how focused we are on the efficiency ratio. And if you just -- if we do the math, when you look at the decline in revenues and -- what the revenue environment looks like, for us, to hit our efficiency ratio targets, we'll have to keep our ti
componenttext: Ken, you know how focused we are on the efficiency ratio. And if you just -- if we do the math, when you look at the decline in revenues and -- what the revenue environment looks like, for us, to hit our efficiency ratio targets, we'll have to keep our tight lid on expenses and therefore, the bottom end of that range, looks more likely relative to the size of the full range we've previously given.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And Aleem, my follow-up just on the comment you'd made last quarter, you had been talking previously but running and also in the $1.2-ish [ph] billion on NII, this quarter it looks like you started low but below that, maybe partly because it day cou
componenttext: Okay. And Aleem, my follow-up just on the comment you'd made last quarter, you had been talking previously but running and also in the $1.2-ish [ph] billion on NII, this quarter it looks like you started low but below that, maybe partly because it day count. But kind of the same follow-up, just, as we kind of also just stuck at this 1 -- sub $1.2 billion level, just given where we are in the rate environment for now?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think yes, that day count was an issue this quarter, Ken and also, the premium amortization this quarter on the securities portfolio, was an issue, just given the big lurch down in the rates that we got this quarter, yes, 30 basis points on the 10
componenttext: Well, I think yes, that day count was an issue this quarter, Ken and also, the premium amortization this quarter on the securities portfolio, was an issue, just given the big lurch down in the rates that we got this quarter, yes, 30 basis points on the 10-year. So I think if you take those 2 things out and I think about what NII looks like over the course of the remainder of the year, we've been actually very successful in holding NII stable despite declining margins for many quarters until we got to this quarter. We got to step down this quarter because of the decline in the swap income. But from here, I would think that we are -- if this is of the trough in NII, then this is very close to the trough.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was wondering on the mortgage side, the production revenues, as you noted, were quite strong on both volume and margins. I was wondering if you could offer any color on the timing of the volume pickup? Was that steady throughout the quarter, was it spor
componenttext: I was wondering on the mortgage side, the production revenues, as you noted, were quite strong on both volume and margins. I was wondering if you could offer any color on the timing of the volume pickup? Was that steady throughout the quarter, was it sporadic based on where rates were? And then on the gain-on-sale margins, any numerical context you could offer for how strong your gain on sale margins have been and what's been driving that and do you think you could hold these gain-on-sale margins here?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hi, John. Yes, I think that we saw that decline in rates early in the quarter and that helped us on mortgage revenue overall. And production volumes were generally steady throughout the quarter. Margins picked up a little bit early in the quarter and so I
componenttext: Hi, John. Yes, I think that we saw that decline in rates early in the quarter and that helped us on mortgage revenue overall. And production volumes were generally steady throughout the quarter. Margins picked up a little bit early in the quarter and so I think held relatively steady also fairly throughout the quarter. So if rates are where they are, then I would expect this to continue for a while. But also, the refi benefit, I think, continues to decline a little bit, just given how many of our clients have already refi-ed. And over time, the benefit we expect to see from an improving economy is actually, our clients moving more and more toward a purchase market and we're looking forward to seeing that happen.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm more excited about the purchase opportunity going forward. I mean, the refi thing would sort of indicate sort of tenth [ph] of -- even itself out a little bit. So I mean, the real long-term sustainable growth comes from purchase. And what we're s
componenttext: Yes, I'm more excited about the purchase opportunity going forward. I mean, the refi thing would sort of indicate sort of tenth [ph] of -- even itself out a little bit. So I mean, the real long-term sustainable growth comes from purchase. And what we're seeing and maybe it's unique in our market, but we're seeing really good activity on the purchase side.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: We don't tend to provide a full year outlook as it relates to that particular line. But that being said, given what we see right now in the pipeline, given what we see in activity, given what we're feeling from our clients, I mean, we continue to feel rea
componenttext: We don't tend to provide a full year outlook as it relates to that particular line. But that being said, given what we see right now in the pipeline, given what we see in activity, given what we're feeling from our clients, I mean, we continue to feel really good about that business. It's got quarter-to-quarter type fluctuations. But if you do sort of a straight line for us over multi-quarter, you're seeing a continued improvement and given the investments we've made there, the receptivity from our clients, I don't see a reason that would continue.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just a similar question on deposit service charges, they are a bit weaker than I think we were expecting, so I was just curious if you can provide an outlook on that level of line item?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just a similar question on deposit service charges, they are a bit weaker than I think we were expecting, so I was just curious if you can provide an outlook on that level of line item?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, there were a little bit lower, primarily, again. We had 2 fewer days this quarter, as well as we're seeing changes in client behavior. Our clients are consolidating accounts and they're looking to try to find ways of avoiding fees. And we're wo
componenttext: Yes, well, there were a little bit lower, primarily, again. We had 2 fewer days this quarter, as well as we're seeing changes in client behavior. Our clients are consolidating accounts and they're looking to try to find ways of avoiding fees. And we're working with them to do that. We're educating our clients on what they can do, and we think that over the long run, that's going to help our overall client relationships and help build the franchise. So if I look to deposit service charges over the remaining part of the year, that'll be driven a little bit by our client behavior. But I think we're looking for ways to try and work with our clients and this is not going to be an overall growth area for the company. But we're looking to trying to find ways to work with our clients and help them manage their exposure, and we think that'll help our relationships in the long term.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: And they're obviously inversely related to deposit growth. We've seen really good deposit growth, in not only new account acquisition but just increase in balances and individual account.
componenttext: And they're obviously inversely related to deposit growth. We've seen really good deposit growth, in not only new account acquisition but just increase in balances and individual account.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mr. Ryan Nash from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mr. Ryan Nash from Goldman Sachs.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little bit about the loan growth you saw this quarter, where the slowdown came from, particularly on the commercial side, which is where I think you had one of your slowest quarters in a while, just how big were the elevated paydowns in the
componenttext: Can you talk a little bit about the loan growth you saw this quarter, where the slowdown came from, particularly on the commercial side, which is where I think you had one of your slowest quarters in a while, just how big were the elevated paydowns in the quarter?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'll take that one. The C&I was up about 2% this quarter overall. And most of our core verticals, we continue to see some pretty good growth. Some assumptions to that, particularly in the areas where we've been focused on returns, equipment leasing w
componenttext: Yes. I'll take that one. The C&I was up about 2% this quarter overall. And most of our core verticals, we continue to see some pretty good growth. Some assumptions to that, particularly in the areas where we've been focused on returns, equipment leasing would be one of those, some of that's involved with the loan sale of some muni assets that we just didn't see being as strategic long-term as we wanted. And some that was flat this quarter. That was mainly from pay-downs and that sort of as a two-edged sword. I mean, the 1 edge is it reduces your growth a little bit but on the other edge is like a nice confirmation of our business. So we got paid out some construction activity and investor demand being very good, so the things that we're financing are very financeable in the secondary market so that's positive. I think going forward, on the C&I side, we continue to be positive. I think the pay-downs were probably a little higher this quarter than certainly, than we've seen in the past. Production engines are continuing to be positive, may not be the same level as last year, but it continue to see growth.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. Aleem you noted 2 [ph] to 4 [ph] basis points of NIM pressure in the second quarter. Just given the focus on relationship, pricing, clearly seeing our yields are still under pressure, do uoui think that 2 to 4 is going to be a good run rate absent
componenttext: Got it. Aleem you noted 2 [ph] to 4 [ph] basis points of NIM pressure in the second quarter. Just given the focus on relationship, pricing, clearly seeing our yields are still under pressure, do uoui think that 2 to 4 is going to be a good run rate absent any changes to the swap portfolio to the remainder of the year, or could we actually see the pressure start to ease, like I said, just given the focus on getting better pricing across your customer base?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ryan, I think that's a question about sort of the economy and markets. And if the economic growth picks up, I think that, that amount of decline will decline. But if we stay as we are, all else equal, I would think that, that kind of a margin decline, 2 o
componenttext: Ryan, I think that's a question about sort of the economy and markets. And if the economic growth picks up, I think that, that amount of decline will decline. But if we stay as we are, all else equal, I would think that, that kind of a margin decline, 2 or 3 basis points a quarter, is about sort of the kind of grind down that we would continue to see given runoffs and new production over the remainder of the year.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Erika Najarian from Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Erika Najarian from Bank of America.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: My first question is actually a follow-up to Ryan's question. So throughout your prepared remarks, you mentioned several times that you continue to want to keep your return hurdles high as you think about balance sheet growth. And you also noted that C&I
componenttext: My first question is actually a follow-up to Ryan's question. So throughout your prepared remarks, you mentioned several times that you continue to want to keep your return hurdles high as you think about balance sheet growth. And you also noted that C&I loan growth may not be as strong as last year. At the same time, Wholesale Banking continues to be strong and your particular markets are also quite strong. As we think about loan growth for the balance of the year compared to last year and we mix all of those together, could you still have accelerating loan growth despite some of what you pointed out?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we can have a good loan growth in our markets. You know the markets we're in, where we've got great opportunity, we've certainly put a lot of investment in great talent that we've been fortunate enough to bring in over the last couple of yea
componenttext: Well, I think we can have a good loan growth in our markets. You know the markets we're in, where we've got great opportunity, we've certainly put a lot of investment in great talent that we've been fortunate enough to bring in over the last couple of years. I think that's going to help us on the loan growth side. But to your question about returns, I think along with loan growth and net interest income, of course, there's fee income. And I think our strategy around being able to grow noninterest income from that client base to whom we provide the value proposition that they like, I think, is -- we've been able to demonstrate that we've been able to deliver that, and it gave us a testament to the talent we brought in. And that our investment banking results this quarter, I think, demonstrate that, that strategy is working well for us.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I think the -- there's no putting brakes on the production engines. I mean, we're continuing to fire on all cylinders and making sure that we're seeing the kind of opportunities that we want to see. 1 of the big trade-offs in the overall balances
componenttext: Yes. And I think the -- there's no putting brakes on the production engines. I mean, we're continuing to fire on all cylinders and making sure that we're seeing the kind of opportunities that we want to see. 1 of the big trade-offs in the overall balances analysis are in the consumer our private wealth side and I really like the trade. I mean, our Consumer Direct business was up about 9%. Our indirect was down about 8%, and I like that trade. It's more client-related business. It's higher-margin business, and continued sort of equal credit quality. So I think that kind of trade on the balance sheet, particularly as it relates to consumer side, something that we'll continue to be focused on.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Understood. And just from my second question, taking a step back, M&A is a big with bank investors today than even a quarter ago. Given your level of access capital and the environment being challenging for all banks, do you see yourself as a potential ac
componenttext: Understood. And just from my second question, taking a step back, M&A is a big with bank investors today than even a quarter ago. Given your level of access capital and the environment being challenging for all banks, do you see yourself as a potential acquirer over the next 12 to 18 months? And how does that mindset perhaps, change versus, let's say, 10 years ago?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the continued investment right now is in our business, the bank the we like the most is SunTrust. We've got the third-biggest retail operation in our market, the fourth largest mortgage company, we've got great momentum in our investment ban
componenttext: Well, I think the continued investment right now is in our business, the bank the we like the most is SunTrust. We've got the third-biggest retail operation in our market, the fourth largest mortgage company, we've got great momentum in our investment banking operations. So we're really going to continue to invest in those things, funded by some of the expense savings and opportunities that we're creating. I presume we'd have the green light if we wanted to do something on the M&A side, when we think about things that are potentially accretive to a really strong franchise? Yes, but those are not a lot of them. So the 12 to 18 months is a longtime. Our focus right now continues to be highly and mostly focused on SunTrust.

componenttext: So we sold $2 billion towards the end of Q4, and in Q1, we moved another $400 million into held-for-sale.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then I'm just also wondering, is -- are you through that process, is there more to come? How are you making decisions, which ones to sell? I assume that's relative value on the risk-adjusted margins, but just how far along in the process you are?
componenttext: And then I'm just also wondering, is -- are you through that process, is there more to come? How are you making decisions, which ones to sell? I assume that's relative value on the risk-adjusted margins, but just how far along in the process you are?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. You're exactly right, we're looking for relative value. We're looking for lower ROA or ROE loans. We're also looking for loans that, as Bill said earlier, are more in the indirect space, loans were we don't have a client, a relationship with that clie
componenttext: No. You're exactly right, we're looking for relative value. We're looking for lower ROA or ROE loans. We're also looking for loans that, as Bill said earlier, are more in the indirect space, loans were we don't have a client, a relationship with that client. So if we find loans that fit those categories, we'd rather put our capital to work for clients where we do have a relationship and where we get returns that hit our hurdles rates.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: And so just a as these question as these, are you pretty much done, or this is ongoing which you expected type of level of loan sales happened [ph] for the [ph] business?
componenttext: And so just a as these question as these, are you pretty much done, or this is ongoing which you expected type of level of loan sales happened [ph] for the [ph] business?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're doing an ongoing search, Betsy. And if we find portfolios of loans that fit our sale category, then we'll be continuing to look for exit on those loans and put our money to work where we think it actually makes more sense. If you go back over the la
componenttext: We're doing an ongoing search, Betsy. And if we find portfolios of loans that fit our sale category, then we'll be continuing to look for exit on those loans and put our money to work where we think it actually makes more sense. If you go back over the last couple of years, I think you'll see sort of us per -- on a pretty steady basis, moving lower ROA assets out of our balance sheet not to somebody else's.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. My follow-up is just on the impact of some of the regulatory rules around leverage lending, and I know you had a very strong business there. Maybe you could speak to how you see that shaking out for investors, especially as your energy has pulled ba
componenttext: Okay. My follow-up is just on the impact of some of the regulatory rules around leverage lending, and I know you had a very strong business there. Maybe you could speak to how you see that shaking out for investors, especially as your energy has pulled back a bit in terms of these funding?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think  -- you're certainly are seeing some shakeout in the market. That's not the biggest driver of our and, going forward. It has been a driver. It's something I think we've participated in and a very thoughtful way that's very consistent
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think  -- you're certainly are seeing some shakeout in the market. That's not the biggest driver of our and, going forward. It has been a driver. It's something I think we've participated in and a very thoughtful way that's very consistent with our strategy of being highly diversified. And both inter and intra, our parts of our portfolio. And I think overall, it's positive. Overall, think were seeing other bit of a pull back to what we've seen a couple of quarters ago and I think overall for a business, in general, that's a positive and will be a positive for us.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from John Pancari from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from John Pancari from Evercore ISI.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just want to get the low more color on what are your detailed that you gave around loan growth in the pay-downs, et cetera, and what that means for overall growth in the coming quarters? I know that there's questions about it in the call already. But is i
componenttext: Just want to get the low more color on what are your detailed that you gave around loan growth in the pay-downs, et cetera, and what that means for overall growth in the coming quarters? I know that there's questions about it in the call already. But is it fair to assume that you're going to be in a growth rate in the mid-single digits as you have been in prior quarters, or are the pay-downs and some of your selectivity in what you're putting on the balance sheet, could that weigh on it near-term, or could we look at it low single digits?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, John, you made an important point, is I think we're going to grow in the areas that we want to continue to grow in. And they have been growing. If we look at areas like core commercial and our corporate banking business and said, virtually,
componenttext: Yes. I think, John, you made an important point, is I think we're going to grow in the areas that we want to continue to grow in. And they have been growing. If we look at areas like core commercial and our corporate banking business and said, virtually, all of our verticals, I mean, we're seeing real growth, and we would expect that to continue. That's been offset that a little bit this quarter, may be uniquely by higher pay-downs in the CRE side, which we discussed, which again sort of on balance, I view as positive in terms of the confirmation of our business model. And then also, with the decisions that we made in the fourth quarter relative to particular loan sales. So trust me, as I said earlier, we're not putting the rates on loan growth. I mean, we're continuing to be very positive about the businesses that we're in, we're very positive about the markets that we're in, and continue to see opportunities in that area. And much of what we're doing is meeting our hurdle requirements. And a lot of it hurdle requirements because of the investments we've made on the fee-based side. The fact that we've gone -- come a long way from a spend only business, we are able to generate a lot more income off the commitments that we make on the asset side. So I continue to feel good about the capacity to generate loan growth in this company, and I think the first quarter is just a little bit of above an aberration in the sense of pay-downs and then fourth quarter loan sales that are all culminating in 1 particular quarter.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, if you go back to last year, you will see that were putting about $2.5 billion of organic loan growth every quarter. And if we wanted to continue to generate that given the strength of our production engines, I'm sure we could easily do that. The is
componenttext: John, if you go back to last year, you will see that were putting about $2.5 billion of organic loan growth every quarter. And if we wanted to continue to generate that given the strength of our production engines, I'm sure we could easily do that. The issue is at at what returns. And given our focus on overall returns, I don't think that we will choose to grow loans at the same rate that we were last quarter. Certainly, not the rate of Q1 '15 but probably, somewhere in the middle between where we were this quarter and we were last year.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, and you just -- I'm sorry, when you just said versus last, fourth quarter last year?
componenttext: I'm sorry, and you just -- I'm sorry, when you just said versus last, fourth quarter last year?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, all of last year, we were putting on average of about $2.5 billion of loan growth per quarter.
componenttext: Well, all of last year, we were putting on average of about $2.5 billion of loan growth per quarter.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, okay, all right. And then my follow-up is in the expense side -- thanks to the detail around the overall $1.3 billion level. In getting there, I just wanted to get other bit more color on the different components, specifically, operating losses, obvi
componenttext: Yes, okay, all right. And then my follow-up is in the expense side -- thanks to the detail around the overall $1.3 billion level. In getting there, I just wanted to get other bit more color on the different components, specifically, operating losses, obviously lower-than-expected, the outside processing and so forth costs also lower and then I know credit and collection was lower and now it's part of your other classification. So for those types of items, all fair to assume they stay low and they're the main drivers of your confidence around this $1.3 billion?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, there was a little benefit in operating losses this quarter that was sort of a little bit of a one-off. But overall, we're focused on every one of those lines. We continue to work with our teammates across the company around improving overall efficie
componenttext: Yes, there was a little benefit in operating losses this quarter that was sort of a little bit of a one-off. But overall, we're focused on every one of those lines. We continue to work with our teammates across the company around improving overall efficiency ratio, finding dollars of expenses that we can cut in those context. We've talked in the past about all of our various strategies, all of the things that we're focused on to continue to manage expenses and grow efficiency. And we've talked less about those now but that doesn't mean they've gone away. We continue to focus on that than I expect that we'll continue to do that over the remainder of the year, John.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. John, you mentioned a few line items which are somewhat cyclical by nature and I think continuing the trends that we're on, we should overall, maybe not quarter-to-quarter, maybe seeing those continue to go down as the quality of our portfolio improv
componenttext: Yes. John, you mentioned a few line items which are somewhat cyclical by nature and I think continuing the trends that we're on, we should overall, maybe not quarter-to-quarter, maybe seeing those continue to go down as the quality of our portfolio improves. But then as Aleem pointed out, then it's everything else in the shows the call way we run our business. I mean, lots of focus on operations cost, looking at lender centers, call centers, technology infrastructure, end-to-end focus and virtually all of our businesses, corporate real estate consolidation, use of third parties, vendor management, i mean, the list goes on. I mean, we're just highly focused on more than 2 or 3 lines as it relates to improving that expense line. But we also noted the focus is on the efficiency ratio because we're also investing. So we're sort of in the save a dollar, invest a dollar kind of mode right now because we see lots of opportunities to continue to invest in our company for long-term growth and we're going to be careful about hitting that right balance of not cutting into the sort of the core revenue capacity opportunities in our company, again, which I think, are significant long-term.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Matt Burnell from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Matt Burnell from Wells Fargo.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Actually, it's Jason for Matt's team. So yes, first question is just on the swaps. Looks like you guys updated that is, thereby about 10% for the full year. I'm just curious, what's driving that, and what your appetite would be to purchase additional swap
componenttext: Actually, it's Jason for Matt's team. So yes, first question is just on the swaps. Looks like you guys updated that is, thereby about 10% for the full year. I'm just curious, what's driving that, and what your appetite would be to purchase additional swaps within the context of the fiscal year rising later this year?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm not sure rates will rise later this year. But yes, as you noted, we did add a little bit more into that portfolio. Remember, we -- how many we have rolloff in the first quarter and given the way that our portfolio looks structurally and if we di
componenttext: Well, I'm not sure rates will rise later this year. But yes, as you noted, we did add a little bit more into that portfolio. Remember, we -- how many we have rolloff in the first quarter and given the way that our portfolio looks structurally and if we did nothing at all, 60% of our overall loans would be floating-rate. And we continue to want to add swaps to move some of that portfolio to what looks like fixed-rate. And as a result of the swaps that we have on the book now, we're more like 50-50. So we've got, what I think today, is a nice, balanced portfolio that prepares us to be asset-sensitive for some point in the future. I'm not so sure that point in the future is going to be soon, i.e. in the next few months. But I think as you look out to 2016 and '17, our investors are going to want us to be asset-sensitive, and I think our swaps structure and overall structural rate book allows us to be nicely asset-sensitive at that point.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I think, Aleem mentioned, and we mentioned in January, coming in into this year, we geared our planning process not thinking about a rate increase. And when we talk about efficiency ratio, when we talk about the things that we are we have control of,
componenttext: And I think, Aleem mentioned, and we mentioned in January, coming in into this year, we geared our planning process not thinking about a rate increase. And when we talk about efficiency ratio, when we talk about the things that we are we have control of, we're assuming we're going to be in a low rate environment. Now if that changes, we obviously get the benefit of that, and we're obviously positioned for that long term. But we're not dependent on our rate increase, for example, to hit our sub-63% efficiency ratio.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's very helpful. And then just to maybe switch over from my follow-up on the credit card business, it looks like you're making some nice progress there. Can you comment, specifically on what you're seeing there and may be sharing insights into t
componenttext: Okay, that's very helpful. And then just to maybe switch over from my follow-up on the credit card business, it looks like you're making some nice progress there. Can you comment, specifically on what you're seeing there and may be sharing insights into the appetite of your customers to revolve balances?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, that's a -- it is part of that direct portfolio that we're seeing grow in our consumer side and we're actually very pleased with what we've seeing in the credit card side. Not only are we putting more cards in in everybody, we're actually bee
componenttext: Yes. I mean, that's a -- it is part of that direct portfolio that we're seeing grow in our consumer side and we're actually very pleased with what we've seeing in the credit card side. Not only are we putting more cards in in everybody, we're actually been on the chart now pretty consistently for about 12 to 18 months. But as you point it out, we're actually now starting to see utilization. So some of the things that we're doing to activate that with different campaigns and process that we're running to making sure that we've got reward programs and et cetera, that are highly competitive. And we're just seeing clients are starting to shift that as their overall usage to a more fulsome relationship that they have with SunTrust versus maybe, a single relationship they have with somebody else with their cards in their wallet. So I'm hopeful that trend will continue and I like the momentum we've established.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mr. Gerard Cassidy from RBC.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mr. Gerard Cassidy from RBC.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you share with us on your ability to purchase up to $875 million now of your common shares between the second quarter '15 and '16, is that going to be a straight line, even amount per quarter, or will it be variable? And plus, if some opportunity came
componenttext: Can you share with us on your ability to purchase up to $875 million now of your common shares between the second quarter '15 and '16, is that going to be a straight line, even amount per quarter, or will it be variable? And plus, if some opportunity came up to buy stock more aggressively, if it's not in your sheet card plan, can you still do it or do you have to apply to the regulators to say that you want to do it?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Gerard, to answer your second question first, the overall program is regulated quite rigorously. So if we wanted to make dramatic changes, I'm sure would be having a conversation. And coming via to your first question, I expect that to be relatively
componenttext: Well, Gerard, to answer your second question first, the overall program is regulated quite rigorously. So if we wanted to make dramatic changes, I'm sure would be having a conversation. And coming via to your first question, I expect that to be relatively even over the 5-quarter period. In the first quarter of this year, we repurchased $115 million of stock and I'm pleased with the increase over the next few quarters that was not objective glove that will be able to bring that stock in.

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Coming back to your to Tier 1 Common ratio which is very strong, at 9.8%, first, what are you comfortable that running at? And second, I know this this putting the cart before the horse, but for next year's CCAR program, if you feel you have excess capita
componenttext: Coming back to your to Tier 1 Common ratio which is very strong, at 9.8%, first, what are you comfortable that running at? And second, I know this this putting the cart before the horse, but for next year's CCAR program, if you feel you have excess capital, what is the possibility or probability that you would ask for the buyback more than your current earnings which American Express, for example, did this year?

headline: SunTrust Banks, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, like what we were able to do this year, Gerard, when we took overall payout ratio from the 50% range up to the 70% range. So that was nice to be able to do. And given the context of continued loan growth, we'd need to retain some level of capital in
componenttext: Well, like what we were able to do this year, Gerard, when we took overall payout ratio from the 50% range up to the 70% range. So that was nice to be able to do. And given the context of continued loan growth, we'd need to retain some level of capital in order to be able to support the loan growth that we're going to get this year. As I look forward to where we think we can be at some point in the future, I do think, like you, that 9.8% overall and remember, that this is on a fully phase-in basis, but that's probably more than we'll need. And I would hope that over the course of the medium term, that the regulators would allow the industry to be able to shrink capital levels overall. If I think about where we could end up in that type of environment, I think that we would likely end up at some kind of ratio below 9%, somewhere -- something that starts with an 8, it probably seems like it would be certainly adequate for the needs that we have as a company to support our client needs and be able to withstand the rigors of the CCAR stress test.
